title: 114_s2182
content:
The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" is also known as the "Cut" Act. It modifies the Congressional Budget Act by adding spending limits. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" sets spending limits for fiscal year 2016 to prevent exceeding specified budget authority and outlays. Adjustments can be made for bills related to the global war on terrorism. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" allows the chair of the House or Senate Committee on the Budget to adjust spending limits for congressional enforcement based on new budget authority related to the global war on terrorism. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 allows the House or Senate Committee on Appropriations to adjust suballocations for new budget authority related to the Global War on Terrorism for fiscal year 2016. The House reported appropriations for fiscal year 2016, allocating up to $58 billion for Overseas Contingency Operations/Global War on Terrorism. SEC. 317. CERTAIN SPENDING LIMITS. The House of Representatives and the Senate cannot consider any bill that would exceed specified spending limits, except for certain exempt functions like Social Security, Medicare, Veterans Benefits, Net Interest, and Military personnel accounts. SEC. 102. STATUTORY ENFORCEMENT OF SPENDING CAPS THROUGH SEQUESTRATION. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a new section 318 for enforcing discretionary and direct spending caps. Implementation of sequesters includes discretionary spending limits in section 316 and direct spending enforcement under section 254 of the Balanced Budget Act of 1985. The Balanced Budget Act of 1985 exempts certain payments from sequestration, including military personnel accounts, TRICARE for Life, Medicare, military retirement, Social Security, veterans, net interest, and discretionary appropriations. Presidential Order can be modified by the Director at any time. The Balanced Budget Act of 1985 exempts specific payments from sequestration. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget can modify the Presidential Order after issuing a sequestration report. Section 258A of the Act applies to bills in the House and Senate that aim to override the order with equivalent budget reductions. The joint resolution would achieve reductions in new budget authority and outlays for the fiscal year as set forth in the order. A point of order prohibits considering a bill or joint resolution that alters a sequestration order without certification of equivalent reductions in budget authority and outlays. TITLE II--CAP

SEC. 201. LIMIT ON TOTAL SPENDING. Section 250(c) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to redefine the term 'GDP' as the gross domestic product consistent with Department of Commerce definitions. Additionally, Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a new section after section 318. "SEC. 319. ENFORCING GDP OUTLAY LIMITS." The term 'GDP outlay limit' refers to an estimated amount calculated by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget based on projected GDP for each fiscal year, with specific percentages set for fiscal years 2016 to 2022. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget sets specific percentages for GDP outlay limits for fiscal years 2021 to 2025. Total federal outlays include all on-budget and off-budget expenditures. Total federal outlays, including on-budget and off-budget expenditures, will be subject to sequestration as per the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Certain programs are exempt from this section, such as military personnel accounts, TRICARE for Life, Medicare, military retirement, Social Security, veterans, and net interest. Certain programs, including military retirement, Social Security, veterans, and net interest, shall be exempt from sequestration under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. SEC. 320. ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES added to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 for enforcement mechanisms. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 includes enforcement procedures to prevent exceeding GDP outlay limits. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 requires a balanced budget amendment to be submitted to states. The Secretary of the Treasury cannot use additional borrowing authority until a balanced budget amendment is sent to the States, which includes limits on outlays, a spending cap as a percentage of GDP, and requires a \2/3\ vote for tax increases. It is not allowed in the House or Senate to consider any bill without meeting these requirements. The Secretary of the Treasury is prohibited from using additional borrowing authority until a balanced budget amendment is sent to the States, which includes various fiscal constraints. It is not permitted in Congress to consider any bill without meeting these requirements.
